text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This manual provides policies and guidance to Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) Field Examination, Campus Examination, Headquarters Examination, and Examination Specialty Programs, hereby referred to as SB/SE Examination, managers and IDRS Unit Security Representatives to carry out their respective responsibilities regarding security of the Integrated Retrieval System (IDRS) and other applications that contain taxpayer data.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
Small Business/Self-Employed, Campus Examination, Field Examination, Headquarters Examination, and Examination Specialty Programs, Managers and IDRS Unit Security Representatives.
Small Business/Self Employed Examination Case Selection

Security for Examination

) Purpose: This IRM section provides policies and guidance to carry out tive responsibilities regarding security of the Integrated Data Retrieval (IDRS) and other applications, which contain taxpayer return and return mation. (

) Audience: This IRM is directed toward Small Business/Self Employed Campus Examination, Field Examination, Headquarters Examination and amination Specialty Programs, Managers and IDRS Unit Security Representatives. The audience includes the following operations: • Campus Examination • Field Examination • Headquarters Examination • Examination Specialty Programs • Planning and Special Programs (PSP) • Technical Services (East, West, Mid-States, Legacy) (
) Policy Owner: The Director, SB/SE Examination is responsible for issuing policy. (
) Program Owner: The program owner is Examination Case Selection. (

) Primary Stakeholders: Area-wide SB/SE Examination IDRS Security tatives in North Atlantic, Central, South Atlantic, Midwest, Gulf States, Southwest, Specialty and Campus Examination/Automated Underreporter Program (AUR). (

) Program Goals: The primary goal of this IRM is to provide procedural guidance, which will ensure consistency across the organization. This the timely review and certiﬁcation of security reports, addressing user inquiries not detailed in another IRM. (
) Contact Information: To recommend changes or make any other related to this IRM section, see IRM
, Providing Feedback About IRM Section - Outside of Clearance. (

, IDRS and Data Security for Examination, further deﬁnes ments found in IRM
, Information Technology (IT) Security, Policy Guidance, and IRM
, Information Technology (IT) Security, IDRS Security Controls. In the event of a discrepancy, information in IRM Part
takes precedence. (
) The IRM

, Information Technology (IT) Security IDRS Security Controls, Roles and Responsibilities, Manager, states the managers of users are responsible for day-to-day implementation and administration of IDRS security in their group. However, to relieve administrative burden on line managers, SB/SE Examination established dedicated Unit Security sentatives (USRs). (
) USRs are responsible for ensuring all aspects of data security are followed and coordinating with the unit manager where issues may arise. (
) The following three IRMs deﬁne overall IDRS security requirements. a. IRM
, Information Technology (IT) Security, Policy and Internal Revenue Manual #

) The USR is responsible for providing IDRS security support and carrying security duties within their designated Examination Area. Managers of employees who have access to IDRS are responsible for all activities performed on IDRS are within an employee’s required tax administration duties. (
) IRM
, Roles and Responsibility, further deﬁnes the roles of the Security Representative (USR), Alternative USR, Terminal Security tor (TSA), and group manager. (

) SB/SE Examination IDRS Unit Security Representatives, and managers of employees who have access to IDRS and other systems with taxpayer employee information are required to implement security policies and dures to help ensure protection of taxpayer data. (

) USRs and unit managers shall: a. Monitor and review IDRS Online Reports Services (IORS) reports Security Audit and Analysis System (SAAS) work products to ensure security reports are thoroughly reviewed and timely certiﬁed. b. Collaborate with IT Cybersecurity personnel to address emerging c. Utilizes resources to analyze trends of potential threats, misuse or thorized access to taxpayer data. d. Conduct annual operational reviews and develop an annual action for the Area USR. (

) The IORS application will maintain a record of all certiﬁcations by the Report Reviewer for each report requiring certiﬁcation and for each IDRS under the Primary Report Reviewer’s responsibility. (
) Business organizations shall achieve at least a
% certiﬁcation rate for security reports. As outlined in IRM
, Review and Security Reports in IORS. (

) Cybersecurity IDRS Security Analysts shall: a. Review IORS utility reports to determine whether IORS Primary Reviewers in their campus domain(s) are reviewing IDRS Security reports in a timely manner, certifying the reports, and taking the ate action, as needed. b. At least weekly provide business organizations in their campus with a report listing uncertiﬁed reports. c. Work with business organizations in their campus domain(s) to IDRS security report certiﬁcation related issues. d. Advise business organizations within their campus domain(s) of any where a Primary Report Reviewer has not been designated. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Term Deﬁnition Audit Trail A chronological record of trans- actions entered on IDRS or related applications. Automated Command Code A feature designed to prevent Access Control IDRS users with certain roles from having speciﬁed command codes in their proﬁles. i.e., use command codes RSTRK or BYPAS. Campus domain A controlled area of IDRS campuses and their servers. Certiﬁcation Refers to the process by which security reports have been analyzed, reviewed, docu- mented and veriﬁed as appropriate. Command Code A ﬁve-character terminal input on IDRS to extract a speciﬁc set of data or used to input an action. Deﬁner The sixth character of a command code used to extract speciﬁc data. Head of Office Designee Designated personnel who oversees Form 11377, Taxpayer Data Access. Security Event An event that could potentially be an unauthorized attempt to the security of IRS systems or data. Unit Manager Supervisor or Acting Supervisor of IDRS Users

IDRS Security Role Designations and Responsibilities are delegated to indi- viduals responsible for overseeing IDRS Security. This IRM section focuses on four security role designations and responsibilities pertinent to IDRS security. They are: • Unit Security Representative (USR) • IORS Primary Report Reviewer • Alternate USR • Terminal Security Administrator (TSA) For more information on security roles and responsibilities for speciﬁc security personnel, operations and functions, see IRM
, Roles and Responsi- bilities.
(07-06-2020) IDRS Security Role Designations and Responsibilities
For more information on security roles and responsibilities for speciﬁc security personnel, operations and functions, see IRM 10.8.34.3, Roles and Responsi-
4.2 General Examining Procedures

The IDRS Unit Security Representative (USR), is an individual assigned by their Business Operating Division (BOD) to implement and administer IDRS security at the IDRS unit level. The USR is sometimes referred to as the “Primary USR,” when there are designated Alternate USRs.

meet the criteria of a USR, the individual must: Be a Non-Bargaining unit (NBU) employee. Have a completed Background Investigation (BI). Prior to performing USR duties, complete initial training course number
, IDRS Unit Security Representatives (USRs). Annually, complete training course number
, IDRS Unit Security Representative (USR) Refresher. Be designated by management via Form

, IDRS Security Personnel Designation. Certify to Enterprise Operations (EOPS) IDRS Security Accounts Admin- istrator that they have completed the required initial and/or annual refresher training. Be in an IDRS unit where they do not have permissions on IORS to review or certify their own transaction(s) on IDRS. Be a member of a designated IDRS unit that contains all security command codes needed to perform their duties. Submit the Online (OL

) to have security command codes added to their proﬁle and to have their IDRS account proﬁled with permissions to support users on all SB/SE home campuses for both the Enterprise Computing Center at Martinsburg (ECC-MTB), and Enterprise Computing Center at Memphis (ECC-MEM).

Perform: Such as: Administrative Tasks • Explain all IDRS security procedures and instructions prior to adding new users on IDRS. • Perform security awareness training when requested by group/unit manager. • Support the program goals of IT Cybersecurity by providing assistance, analysis and recommendations for action to SB/SE Examination. • Coordinate with management and USRs from all Areas to support reorganizations through the SB/SE Request for Organizational Change process. • Supervise a range of IDRS unit numbers aligned with SB/SE Examination, as outlined in IRM Exhibit 10.8.34- 13, IDRS Organization Codes - SB/SE Area. • Conduct regular communication with IDRS users, and unit managers to keeps them abreast of IDRS updates, best practices, new implementations, etc.

Explain all IDRS security procedures and instructions prior to adding new users on IDRS. Perform security awareness training when requested by group/unit manager. Support the program goals of IT Cybersecurity by providing assistance, analysis and recommendations for action to SB/SE Examination. Coordinate with management and USRs from all Areas to support reorganizations through the SB/SE Request for Organizational Change process. Supervise a range of IDRS unit numbers aligned with SB/SE Examination, as outlined in IRM Exhibit
, IDRS Organization Codes - SB/SE Area. Conduct regular communication with IDRS users, and unit managers to keeps them abreast of IDRS updates, best practices, new implementations, etc.

Such as: • Add/delete command codes to/from employee proﬁles with management approval, except for security command codes. • Monitor users’ command code usage/non-usage and take action to remove unneeded command codes. • Unlock IDRS workstations and notify the manager of any questionable activity to cause the workstation to locked. • Process OL
requests to add/delete or modify employee IDRS accounts. • Prepare and submit Form
, IDRS Unit Request, IDRS Online Reports Services (IORS) to establish/ delete IDRS units, and to modify unit proﬁles. • Initiate audit trails, via Form
, Request for Audit Trail Extract, and ensure employees are aware of audit trails. • Oversee the processing o
orm

, IDRS Security Personnel Designation. • Transfer employees between IDRS units within their designated Area, and when requested by the unit manager. • Grant IDRS users access to other IRS campuses’ databases, i.e. (Multiple Accesses Capability- • Add/delete the restriction role on Revenue Agents
), Tax Compliance Officers (GS-
), Estate Tax Attorneys (GS-

) and HQ Analysts. • Maintain a tracking system of active IDRS users, IDRS unit numbers, Users’ Terminal Security Identiﬁcations (TSID), and managers and acting managers. • Maintain a centralized storage of Form
and
-E, Taxpayer Data Access, as the Head of Office Designee (HOD). • Delete users promptly when access to IDRS is not needed. • Lock user’s proﬁle immediately if user is on leave for more than

days and the user has not implemented the user self-lock feature (LOKME). • Unlock user’s proﬁle as requested by the user or manager. • Encourage IDRS users to use the IDRS LOKME feature, which enable users to be pro-active in managing their access to IDRS. • Review IDRS security reports and take appropriate action. • Monitor sensitive command code usage. • Maintain security reports, manuals and handbooks in a locked cabinet when not in use. • Encourage the activation and use of IDRS Password Management in lieu of submitting an OL
Reset request. • Modify the terminal on/off time to coincide with ment approval.

Perform: Such as: Monthly Tasks • Review the Automated IDRS Sign-offs Report, Monthly IDRS Security Proﬁle Report, and Password Manage- ment Report and take necessary action. Quarterly Tasks • The review of the Quarterly RSTRK A Report by Office Identiﬁer (OI) and unit range on IDRS. • The review of the IORS Quarterly reports for informa- tional use and for planning and analysis purposes. • The review of information on the IDRS Unit and USR Database (IUUD) and submit corrections/updates via e-mail to EOPs Security Accounts Administrators to re- ﬂect current information. If a manager is on an acting assignment for less than 60 days, the IUUD does not need to be updated.

Review the Automated IDRS Sign-offs Report, Monthly IDRS Security Proﬁle Report, and Password Manage- ment Report and take necessary action. zation to review IDRS security reports in IORS. There are two IORS Report Reviewer roles: • IORS Primary Report Reviewer • IORS Secondary Report Reviewer The Primary Report Reviewer • Designation is made on Form

, IDRS Security Personnel tion. • Is a non-bargaining unit employee. • Is either the unit manager or the USR. • Is responsible for certifying IORS reports. • May grant secondary permissions to authorized personnel. • May grant a proxy to authorized personnel. The Secondary Report Reviewer: • Receives permissions from a Primary Report Reviewer to view more security reports for a unit or units. • Is a non-bargaining unit employee. • Can be a bargaining unit employee if approved by management authorized by EOPs Security Account Administrators. See IRM

, IORS Secondary Report Reviewer, for more information. • Is usually the manager of an IDRS unit. • Cannot certify security reports. • Cannot grant permissions to other IORS users to view security Alternate USRs assist and/or perform the duties of the Primary USR lateral duty assignment.

Receives permissions from a Primary Report Reviewer to view one or more security reports for a unit or units. Is a non-bargaining unit employee. Can be a bargaining unit employee if approved by management and authorized by EOPs Security Account Administrators. See IRM

, IORS Secondary Report Reviewer, for more detailed information. Is usually the manager of an IDRS unit. Cannot certify security reports. Cannot grant permissions to other IORS users to view security reports.

Alternate USRs can be a bargaining unit or non-bargaining unit employee.

Cannot review another IDRS user’s actions on IORS, but may have access to IORS reports that do not show employee’s actions on IDRS, such as: Weekly Reports - Employee Count, Master Register (Active) and Monthly Reports - Automated IDRS Sign Off and Password Management Activations
Is authorized to have all security command codes.
) A Terminal Security Administrator (TSA) is assigned by their business zation to provide additional IDRS user support in unlocking IDRS users’ proﬁles and terminals only. (
) A TSA may be a bargaining unit or non-bargaining unit employee. (
) A TSA must receive security training from a current USR. (
) A TSA designation is made on Form
, IDRS Security Personnel tion.
(07-06-2020) Front Line Manager of IDRS Users
a. Has overall responsibility for IDRS security within their unit to help all activities performed on IDRS by their employees are business b. Approves OL

s for employees in their unit. c. Works in conjunction with the USR regarding the Weekly and Monthly IORS reviews and certiﬁcations. d. Coordinates with the USR to establish new IDRS units that falls under their jurisdictions. e. Notiﬁes USR immediately when users within their unit no longer need IDRS access. f. Notiﬁes USR when an employee transfers in or out of the unit. g. Reinforces compliance with security awareness guidelines.

General Examining h. Ensures all employees annually recertify the security rules via i. Reviews the appropriate use of the command codes in the Maximum Proﬁle Authorization File (MPAF), and employee proﬁles at least j. Ensures that all requirements associated with a disciplinary action have been met prior to reinstating an IDRS user. k. Ensures questionable activity or potential UNAX violations are timely reported to Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA). (

) Front line Managers of IDRS users may also: a. Request secondary permissions on IORS to view and document reports for their employees. b. Be designated as an Alternate USR or TSA, if officially authorized by approved Form
, IDRS Security Personnel Designation. (

) The USR is the ﬁrst point of contact for IDRS users at the unit level and a. Establish a means of communicating with users via e-mail, Skype, tralized mailbox, or a combination of communication sources. b. Assist users in a timely manner. c. Be able to effectively troubleshoot users’ issues by utilizing tools and resources available, such as the IRM

, IDRS USR Reference Guide, priority alerts, IDRS Security Program website, IDRS Message Board, etc. d. Be able to apply analytic skills to resolve issues. e. Be able to translate instructions in written form and to interpret proce- dures and guidelines to effectively communicate to end users. f. Be proﬁcient in USR duties and responsibilities. (
) Exhibit
identiﬁes common types of user support issues. For a list of IDRS security frequently asked questions and answers, refer to the IDRS Security Program link: asp (

) IDRS units are established based on the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) business organization structure. Each business organization i.e., Small Business/Self-Employed, Wage and Investment, Large Business and tional, and Tax-Exempt and Government Entities, has an assigned Organization Code Range. For SB/SE Examination, the Organization Code Range, Organization, Function and Unit Number Range are shown in IRM Exhibit
: IDRS Organization Codes Overview - SB/SE & Area Offices. (

) To establish an IDRS unit, the USR must make sure that the unit number consistent with the function area as deﬁned in the Treasury Integrated agement (TIMIS) and within the IDRS unit range and organization code as deﬁned by IRM
, IDRS Security Controls. (

) An IDRS Unit Number is a ﬁve-digit number that is categorized as follows: • First and second digits is the Office Identiﬁer( OI) and represent the campus, business organization or Area Office • Third, fourth, and ﬁfth digits represent the organization code the campus, business organization or Area Office Internal Revenue Manual Cat. ) In SB/SE Examination, all units in the same territory should be kept within same block of numbers and to the extent possible, should be sequenced by group, i.e., the ﬁfth digit of the unit number should be the same as the group number as shown in the organization code structure. (
) IDRS units must not contain employees from different business or Area Offices. (

) An IDRS unit may consist of one or more IDRS users who are in the same territory, group, or section. Example: When an employee group only has a IDRS users, users from the same territories may be included in the same IDRS unit. This is known as a “mixed” IDRS unit (employees report to managers but are in the same territory.) A mixed IDRS unit is established to control single users in one IDRS unit. (
) No unit shall have a manager or USR in the same IDRS unit as the they oversee. (
) The USR must coordinate with the manager to create or assign an IDRS that falls under the managers’ jurisdictions. Request to establish an IDRS unit is made on Form
, IDRS Unit via IORS.
(07-06-2020) Maximum Proﬁle Authorization File (MPAF)
4.2 General Examining Procedures ################## #######
) All requests to modify a unit’s MPAF must be submitted on Form
, Unit Request, via IORS. (
) At the IDRS unit level, the USR or manager are authorized to add or delete command codes in the unit’s MPAF. (
) An IDRS unit shall be deleted when there are no active users in the unit. (
) All requests to delete a unit must be submitted on Form
, IDRS Unit Request, via IORS.
Note: A unit shall not be deleted until the Monthly Report has been certiﬁed and the subsequent Monthly Report shows no employees assigned to the unit.
) When an employee transfers between an IDRS unit within the same Area, an OL
is not required. (

) The USR is responsible for transferring the employee’s account on IDRS. The USR shall coordinate with the gaining manager to conﬁrm the appropriate command codes to be added to the transferring employee’s proﬁle.

The USR is responsible for transferring the employee’s account on IDRS. The USR shall coordinate with the gaining manager to conﬁrm the appropriate command codes to be added to the transferring employee’s proﬁle.
Note: This transfer can cross territory lines.
and Data Security for Examination 4.2.9
When an employee transfers within the same business organization, on the same campus with a different Office Identiﬁer (OI), an OL5081 is not required.
When an employee transfers to another business organization within the same campus with a different Office Identiﬁer, an OL5081 is not required.
14 4.2 General Examining Procedures ###### ##### ##### ##### #

The USR must coordinate with the unit manager to delete command from employees’ proﬁles that are unauthorized and/or not being used or needed for their work assignment or position title. The USR must query their units to identify units that contain security codes to ensure security command codes are only in units approved by agement to function as USRs, Alternate USRs or TSAs. The USR must review the status of Alternate USRs and TSAs on a yearly basis to determine if they are still performing back

up USR support. If no longer providing support, ensure the security command codes are from the user’s proﬁle. The USR must review the MPAF to determine if the command codes in UCCP and Limited Proﬁle are appropriate for the work performed by the in the unit.
(07-06-2020) IDRS Command Codes and Usage
The USR must review the MPAF to determine if the command codes in the UCCP and Limited Proﬁle are appropriate for the work performed by the users

(07-06-2020)SensitiveCommand Code Combinations
IORS is a web-based application that makes IDRS security reports available online to IDRS security staffs and authorized business reviewers.
IORS is a web

based application that makes IDRS security reports online to IDRS security staffs and authorized business reviewers. IORS users are authorized to view security reports based on their permissions role. There are two IORS Report Reviewer roles: a. IORS Primary Report Reviewer b. IORS Secondary Report Reviewer Only the Primary Report Reviewer can certify IORS reports. The USR is designated as the Primary Report Reviewer for SB/SE tion IDRS units, and is responsible for reviewing all transactions on and monthly security reports, and certiﬁcation of required reports.
IORS users are authorized to view security reports based on their reviewer permissions role. There are two IORS Report Reviewer roles:

The USR is designated as the Primary Report Reviewer for SB/SE Examina- tion IDRS units, and is responsible for reviewing all transactions on the weekly and monthly security reports, and certiﬁcation of required reports.
and Data Security for Examination 4.2.9
Managers of IDRS users may be designated as Secondary Report Reviewers and can view, add comments, and print IORS reports for their assigned unit.
Note: A unit should not be deleted until the Monthly Report has been certiﬁed and the subsequent Monthly Report shows no employees assigned to unit.
Master Register (Active): This report identiﬁes all active IDRS users by name, IDRS employee number, Social Security Number (SSN), along with in

formation of user’s time on IDRS, time in their currently assigned unit and the status of the user’s background investigation date. This report also includes IDRS users’ Standard Employee Identiﬁer (SEID) and telephone contact number which is helpful to identify case owners on IDRS. The USR shall take the following actions to rectify this report:

Master Register (Active): This report identiﬁes all active IDRS users by name, IDRS employee number, Social Security Number (SSN), along with in- formation of user’s time on IDRS, time in their currently assigned unit and the status of the user’s background investigation date. This report also includes IDRS users’ Standard Employee Identiﬁer (SEID) and telephone contact number which is helpful to identify case owners on IDRS. The USR shall take the following actions to rectify this report:

Validate each unit in the Master Register to identify discrepancies. Take corrective actions necessary, such as, moving users between units, updating phone number in IDRS, and conﬁrming approved pseudonym names.
a. Identify IDRS users with more than 15 automatic sign-offs in a month. b. Advise those users to sign-off IDRS when not in use to prevent an un-
General Examining c. c. Instruct user how to periodically refresh their IDRS session by using command code RFRSH, if IDRS is not required on a continuous (
) Password Management Activations Report (PWMGT): This report lists number of users in each unit who have activated this capability. Where a fails to reﬂect a

% activation rate, the USR must research IDRS to users who have not activated Password Management and take the actions: a. Send an e-mail to the user with instruction on how to activate the Password Management Capability. b. Follow-up to ensure that the activation was successful. See IRM
, Password Management, for more information on this feature. (
) Security Violations Report: This report must be certiﬁed within

days after the report date for the certiﬁcation to be considered timely. This Security Reports report shows accesses made by users on IDRS that generated a security Required) violation. In most cases, security violations occur because of employee However, repeated errors for speciﬁc violations should be discussed and rective measures taken to help reduce the number of errors. See Exhibit
) Sensitive Access (Other/Spouse) Report: This report must be certiﬁed within

calendar days after the report date for the certiﬁcation to be ered timely. This report identiﬁes users who have attempted to or who have accessed other employees’ or the spouses/ex-spouse of other employees’ accounts. Before this report can be certiﬁed, each Social Security Number (SSN) on this report must be researched to determine if the access to other IRS employees’ accounts and/or their spouses’ accounts, was business related. See Exhibit
) Monthly IDRS Security Proﬁle Report: The Monthly Security Proﬁle provides a summary of all transactions performed on IDRS by end users. Security Report report must be certiﬁed within
calendar days after the report date for the Required) certiﬁcation to be considered timely. See Exhibit
) Certiﬁcation of security reports is mandatory. After the review and tion of reports, the USR must complete the Report Level Items as shown in Level Exhibit
) Level action, comments and certiﬁcation will apply to all units. (
) The IUUD Database is a resource where employees can obtain current mation about IDRS units and IDRS security personnel. Unit and USR (
) The IUUD is designed to assist employees, managers and security (IUUD) to locate IDRS users and their managers associated with their ﬁve-digit unit number. (
) The IUUD also identiﬁes the Primary USRs, Alternate USRs, Primary IORS Report Reviewers, TSAs, and managers for all IDRS units within a business organization. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) The USR is responsible for ensuring the accuracy of the information on the IUUD. To accomplish this, the USR shall: a. Review their assigned units at least once a month and submit updates and corrections to EOPs Security Account Administrators b. Utilize the Employee Count Report on IORS to determine units where there are no employees and submit Form

) Unauthorized Access (UNAX) is the willful unauthorized access or inspection taxpayer information, both electronic and paper, and is a crime, punishable upon conviction, by ﬁnes, prison terms and termination of employment. (
) IRS policy only allows employees to access tax returns and return when the information is needed to carry out their tax administration duty. (
) USRs will perform reviews of security reports to help detect unauthorized (UNAX) activities on IDRS and other systems that employees use to access taxpayer information. (
) USRs are responsible for IDRS security. Any IDRS user found not to be following security rules, shall be advised and counseled by management appropriate action must be taken immediately. (

) If an IDRS Security personnel, USR, manager, or other report reviewer en- counters any indication of illegal or improper activity, he/she shall refer the case and ﬁndings to the proper management and/or TIGTA officials. For the telephone number of your local TIGTA office, view the map on their website. (

) IRS employees are never authorized to access their own records or records • their spouse and ex-spouses; • their children; • their parents; • anyone living in their household; • their other close relatives; • friends or neighbors with whom they have close relationships; • celebrities, when the information is not needed to carry out tax related duties; • an individual or organization for which they or their spouse is an trustee, general partner, agent, attorney, consultant, contractor, employee, or member; • any other individual or organization with which they may have a personal or outside business relationship that could raise questions about their impartiality in handling the tax matter. When employees working authorized assigned cases or making personal or telephonic contacts, they can access other IRS employees’ tax records. when the employee working the authorized case knows the other IRS employee, the case must be referred to management for

If the issue is still outstanding, send an • (PWMGT) SINON ERROR e-mail to the user and/or user’s manager to • (PWMGT) RESPONSE ERROR conﬁrm the following: • The user committed these errors. • The violations were not the result of an un- authorized attempt to access IDRS. • The user was able to successfully sign on IDRS. Note: The user does not agree they committed the violations, or the USR research identify possible illegal or improper activity, the USR shall refer their ﬁndings to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administra- tion (TIGTA) officials. Exhibit 4.2.9-1 (Cont. 1) (07-06-2020) Security Violations Report

Violations Report If four or more of the same violation types… Then… CC NOT IN PROFILE 1. Research the user’s proﬁle to determine if the Command Code (CC) was added since the run date of the report. If added, no further action required. 2. Determine if the CC is in the unit’s Maximum Proﬁle Authorization File (MPAF). 3. If CC is in the MPAF, e-mail the user’s manager advising of the security violation made by their employee and to determine if the CC should be added to the user’s proﬁle. 4. If the CC is not in the MPAF, determine if the CC is authorized for SB/SE Examination Op- erations’ use. 5. If authorized, e-mail the user’s manager advising of the security violation made by their employee and to determine if the CC should be added to the unit’s MPAF. 6. If manager approves to have the CC added to the unit’s MPAF, submit Form 9937 via IORS. Also, ensure that the manager advises their employees to perform an SFDISP on IDRS to determine what CCs are in their proﬁle and available for use. 7. If not authorized, email the user’s manager advising of their employee’s attempt to use a command code that is not authorized for their position. Include in the e-mail supporting documentation to support your ﬁndings. 8. Ask the manager to determine why the employee attempted to use the command code and to determine if the violation is non- critical or if further investigation is warranted.
Then…
Research the user’s proﬁle to determine if the Command Code (CC) was added since the run date of the report. If added, no further action required.
Determine if the CC is in the unit’s Maximum Proﬁle Authorization File (MPAF).
If CC is in the MPAF, e-mail the user’s manager advising of the security violation made by their employee and to determine if the CC should be added to the user’s proﬁle.
If the CC is not in the MPAF, determine if the CC is authorized for SB/SE Examination Op- erations’ use.
If authorized, e-mail the user’s manager advising of the security violation made by their employee and to determine if the CC should be added to the unit’s MPAF.
If manager approves to have the CC added to the unit’s MPAF, submit Form
via IORS. Also, ensure that the manager advises their employees to perform an SFDISP on IDRS to determine what CCs are in their proﬁle and available for use.

If not authorized, email the user’s manager advising of their employee’s attempt to use a command code that is not authorized for their position. Include in the e-mail supporting documentation to support your ﬁndings.
Ask the manager to determine why the employee attempted to use the command code and to determine if the violation is non- critical or if further investigation is warranted.
Exhibit 4.2.9-1 (Cont. 2) (07-06-2020) Security Violations Report

If four or more of the same violation types… Then… PROFILE LOCKED 1. Research the employee’s proﬁle to determine the current status. 2. If the employee’s proﬁle is unlocked since the run date of the report, no further action required 3. If the research shows: a. SYS_LOCK: Determine the lock date. The USR shall delete the employee’s proﬁle if it is locked for more than twenty-eight (28) consecutive calendar days, unless the manager has knowledge that the employee will have a deﬁnite need to access IDRS. b. SEC_LOCK: Contact the employee’s manager to determine the current status of the employee. c. SLF_LOCK: (LOKME) Review and verify with manager the dates or time-frame the Self-Lock was set.

This report must be certiﬁed within 14 calendar days after the report date for the certiﬁcation to be considered timely. This report identiﬁes users who have attempted to or who have accessed other employees’ or the spouses/ex-spouse of other employees’ accounts. Before this report can be certiﬁed, each Social Security Number (SSN) on this report must be researched to determine if the access to other IRS employees’ accounts and/or their spouses’ accounts, was business related.
Validate that the access is supported by one of the following:
Direct case assignment.
Related case assignment.
Evidence of cross compliance checks.
Department of Justice or other official requests.
Conﬁrmed input error supported by the identiﬁcation of another assigned case with similar Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN), such as a transposition or formatting error.
A detailed justiﬁcation statement from the manager when the group or certain employees work assignments will generate reoccurring accesses on this report.
When there is no direct case assignment, but the case is controlled on ERCS, the USR shall validate access.
If further research is required to validate the access, then the USR shall use research and analytical tools to:

Determine if the account is controlled on Exam Document ﬁndings on IORS. Return Control System (ERCS) Determine if Form 11377, Taxpayer Data Access, Document ﬁndings on IORS. was submitted E-mail the accessing employee’s manager to Document ﬁndings on IORS. validate the access. The e-mail to the manager must include: • Speciﬁc information to identify the user. • The date and time stamp of the access. • The account accessed. • The command codes accessed. If manager is unable to validate the access, the Document ﬁndings on IORS. USR shall initiate an Audit Trail via Form 9936, Request for Audit Trail Extract If the audit trail does not validate the access the USR must coordinate with the manager and refer the potential UNAX violation to TIGTA.
